docs.title: Globus Go CLI
docs.text: Welcome to the Globus Go CLI documentation! This is a command-line interface for Globus services, built in Go.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Globus Go CLI provides a powerful command-line interface for interacting with Globus services including file transfer, search, groups, flows, timers, and compute. Built in Go, it offers cross-platform support, fast performance, and a single binary distribution.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• 🚀 Single Binary Distribution - No runtime dependencies, just download and run
  • ⚡ Fast Performance - Written in Go for optimal speed and resource usage
  • 🌐 Cross-Platform - Linux, macOS, Windows (including ARM64 architectures)
  • 🔄 Full Service Support - Auth, Transfer, Search, Groups, Flows, Timers, and Compute
  • 📦 Multiple Installation Methods - Homebrew, Scoop, Docker, or direct binary download
  • 🎨 Flexible Output - JSON, text, and formatted output options
  • 🔐 Secure Authentication - OAuth2-based authentication with token management

docs.title: Feature Parity
docs.text: This Go implementation maintains feature parity with the upstream Python Globus CLI (v3.39.0), with the addition of exclusive Compute service support.

docs.title: Supported Services
docs.text: Service Status Description Auth ✅ Complete Authentication and identity management Transfer ✅ Complete File and directory transfer operations Search ✅ Complete Search index management and queries Groups ✅ Complete Group membership and policy management Flows ✅ Complete Workflow automation and management Timers ✅ Complete Scheduled task execution Compute ✅ Complete Distributed computing (Go CLI exclusive)

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you need help or want to report an issue:

  • Check the Command Reference for detailed command documentation
  • Review Common Tasks for practical examples
  • Open an issue on GitHub

docs.title: About This Project
docs.text: The Globus Go CLI is an independent, community-developed project and is not officially affiliated with, endorsed by, or supported by Globus or the University of Chicago. It is maintained by independent contributors and designed to be compatible with the upstream Python CLI.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Ready to get started? Head over to the Installation Guide to install the CLI on your system.

docs.title: Changelog
docs.text:
All notable changes to the Globus Go CLI will be documented in this file.

The format is based on Keep a Changelog, and this project adheres to Semantic Versioning.

docs.title: Added - Major Feature Release 🎉
docs.text:
• Complete Groups Service (12 commands, 80% coverage)
  • Group management: create, list, show, update, delete
  • Membership management: add/remove members, list members
  • Policy management: view and update group policies
  • Role management commands as placeholders (pending SDK support)
  • Complete Timers Service (8 commands, 100% coverage)
  • Timer job management: create, list, show, update, delete
  • Support for one-time, recurring, and cron-based schedules
  • Pause and resume timer functionality
  • Complete Search Service (18 commands, 100% coverage)
  • Index management: create, list, show, update, delete indices
  • Document operations: query and ingest documents
  • Subject management: show and delete subjects
  • Task monitoring: show task status
  • Index role management placeholders (pending SDK support)
  • Complete Flows Service (15 commands, 100% coverage)
  • Flow management: create, list, show, update, delete flows
  • Flow execution: start flows with input and monitoring
  • Run management: list, show, cancel, update runs
  • Run log viewing and flow definition inspection
  • Validation and resume commands as placeholders (pending SDK support)
  • Complete Compute Service (14 commands, 100% coverage) NEW - Not in Python CLI!
  • Endpoint management: list and view compute endpoints
  • Function management: register, list, show, update, delete functions
  • Task execution: run functions, monitor status, cancel tasks
  • List task history
  • Enhanced shell completion with all new services
  • Comprehensive help documentation for all commands

docs.title: Contributing to Globus Go CLI
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to the Globus Go CLI! This document provides guidelines and instructions for contributing.

docs.title: Development Setup
docs.text:
1. Fork and clone the repository
  2. Install dependencies: go mod download
  3. Build the project: make build

docs.title: Development Workflow
docs.text:
1. Create a branch for your feature or bugfix: git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name
  2. Make your changes
  3. Run tests: make test
  4. Run linters: make lint
  5. Run integration tests (requires credentials): make test-integration
  6. Commit your changes following the conventional commits format
  7. Push your branch and create a pull request

docs.title: Integration Testing
docs.text:
Integration tests are crucial for validating that our code works with real Globus services. To run these tests:

  1. Copy the example credentials file: 

    cp .env.test.example .env.test

  2. Edit .env.test and add your test credentials:

  3. GLOBUS_TEST_CLIENT_ID and GLOBUS_TEST_CLIENT_SECRET: Required for all integration tests
  4. GLOBUS_TEST_SOURCE_ENDPOINT and GLOBUS_TEST_DESTINATION_ENDPOINT: Required for transfer tests

  5. GLOBUS_TEST_USERNAME and GLOBUS_TEST_PASSWORD: Required for full authentication tests

  6. Run the integration tests: 

    make test-integration

Integration tests are tagged with //go:build integration and will only run when explicitly requested. They are skipped if required credentials are missing.

docs.title: Coding Standards
docs.text:
• Follow standard Go coding conventions and idioms
  • Use go fmt and golangci-lint to format and lint your code
  • Write tests for new functionality
  • Update documentation as needed
  • Include SPDX license headers in all new files

docs.title: Pull Request Process
docs.text:
1. Ensure your code passes all tests and linting
  2. Update the README.md with details of changes if appropriate
  3. The PR should work for Linux, macOS, and Windows

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text: The Globus Go CLI uses OAuth2 authentication to securely access Globus services.

docs.title: Login
docs.text:
Authenticate with Globus:

globus login

This opens your browser for authentication and stores credentials locally.

docs.title: Authentication Flow
docs.text:
1. Browser Opens - The CLI opens your default browser
  2. Login - Sign in with your institutional or Globus identity
  3. Grant Permissions - Authorize the CLI to access Globus services
  4. Authorization Code - Receive a code to paste back into the terminal
  5. Token Storage - Credentials are stored in ~/.globus/

docs.title: Checking Authentication Status
docs.text:
View your current identity:

globus auth whoami

Check session information:

globus session show

docs.title: Token Location
docs.text:
Tokens are stored in:

  • Linux/macOS: ~/.globus/tokens.json
  • Windows: %USERPROFILE%\.globus\tokens.json

docs.title: Token Refresh
docs.text:
Tokens are automatically refreshed when needed. If refresh fails, you'll need to log in again:

globus login --force

docs.title: Multiple Identities
docs.text:
Link additional identities to your account:

globus session consent

View all linked identities:

globus session show

docs.title: Logout
docs.text:
Remove stored credentials:

globus logout

This removes all tokens from ~/.globus/tokens.json.

docs.title: Client Credentials
docs.text: For automation and scripts, use client credentials instead of user authentication.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
1. Register an application at developers.globus.org
  2. Note your Client ID and Client Secret
  3. Set environment variables:
export GLOBUS_CLIENT_ID="your-client-id"
export GLOBUS_CLIENT_SECRET="your-client-secret"

docs.title: Usage
docs.text: globus login --client-credentials

docs.title: Scopes and Consent
docs.text:
The CLI requests these scopes:

  • openid - Basic identity information
  • profile - User profile details
  • email - Email address
  • urn:globus:auth:scope:transfer.api.globus.org:all - Transfer operations
  • urn:globus:auth:scope:search.api.globus.org:all - Search operations
  • Additional service-specific scopes as needed

docs.title: Login Fails
docs.text:
If login fails:

  1. Check your internet connection
  2. Ensure browser opens correctly
  3. Try globus login --force to force re-authentication
  4. Clear tokens: rm ~/.globus/tokens.json and try again

docs.title: Token Expired
docs.text:
If you see "token expired" errors:

globus login --force

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
If you see permission errors:

  1. Ensure you've consented to all required scopes
  2. Try globus session consent to re-consent
  3. Check that your identity has access to the requested resource

docs.title: Security Best Practices
docs.text:
• Never share tokens - Keep ~/.globus/tokens.json private
  • Use client credentials for automation
  • Logout when done on shared systems
  • Rotate credentials periodically for long-running scripts
  • Set file permissions: chmod 600 ~/.globus/tokens.json

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:

  • Try Common Tasks
  • Review Command Reference

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: The Globus Go CLI can be configured through configuration files, environment variables, and command-line flags.

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
The CLI stores configuration in:

  • Linux/macOS: ~/.globus/config.yml
  • Windows: %USERPROFILE%\.globus\config.yml

docs.title: Viewing Configuration
docs.text:
View current configuration:

globus config show

docs.title: Setting Configuration Values
docs.text:
Set a configuration value:

globus config set KEY VALUE

Examples:

# Set default output format
globus config set output_format json

# Set transfer sync level
globus config set sync_level mtime

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text:
Common configuration options:

Option Description Default output_format Default output format (json, text) json sync_level Transfer sync level mtime debug Enable debug output false

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Environment variables override configuration file settings.

docs.title: Common Variables
docs.text:
# Output format
export GLOBUS_CLI_FORMAT=json

# Enable debug mode
export GLOBUS_CLI_DEBUG=true

# Client credentials
export GLOBUS_CLIENT_ID=your-client-id
export GLOBUS_CLIENT_SECRET=your-client-secret

See Environment Variables for a complete list.

docs.title: Command-Line Flags
docs.text:
Flags override both configuration and environment variables:

globus auth whoami --format text

docs.title: Priority Order
docs.text:
Configuration is resolved in this order (highest to lowest):

  1. Command-line flags - --format json
  2. Environment variables - GLOBUS_CLI_FORMAT=json
  3. Configuration file - ~/.globus/config.yml
  4. Default values

docs.title: Configuration File Format
docs.text:
The configuration file uses YAML format:

# ~/.globus/config.yml
output_format: json
sync_level: mtime
debug: false

docs.title: Resetting Configuration
docs.text:
Remove a configuration value:

globus config unset KEY

Reset all configuration:

rm ~/.globus/config.yml

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: The Globus Go CLI can be installed using multiple methods depending on your platform and preferences.

docs.title: Homebrew (macOS and Linux)
docs.text:
The easiest way to install on macOS or Linux is using Homebrew:

# Add the tap
brew tap scttfrdmn/tap

# Install the CLI
brew install globus-go-cli

To upgrade to the latest version:

brew upgrade globus-go-cli

docs.title: Scoop (Windows)
docs.text:
For Windows users, Scoop provides an easy installation method:

# Add the bucket
scoop bucket add scttfrdmn https://github.com/scttfrdmn/scoop-bucket

# Install the CLI
scoop install globus-go-cli

To upgrade:

scoop update globus-go-cli

docs.title: Docker
docs.text:
Run the CLI using Docker without installing:

# Run a command
docker run --rm -it scttfrdmn/globus-go-cli:latest auth whoami

# Create an alias for convenience
alias globus='docker run --rm -it -v ~/.globus:/root/.globus scttfrdmn/globus-go-cli:latest'

The -v ~/.globus:/root/.globus mount preserves your authentication tokens between runs.

docs.title: Direct Binary Download
docs.text: Download pre-built binaries from the GitHub Releases page.

docs.title: Linux
docs.text:
# Download the latest release (replace VERSION with actual version)
wget https://github.com/scttfrdmn/globus-go-cli/releases/download/VERSION/globus-go-cli_Linux_x86_64.tar.gz

# Extract
tar -xzf globus-go-cli_Linux_x86_64.tar.gz

# Move to PATH
sudo mv globus /usr/local/bin/

# Verify installation
globus --version

docs.title: macOS
docs.text:
# Download the latest release (replace VERSION with actual version)
curl -LO https://github.com/scttfrdmn/globus-go-cli/releases/download/VERSION/globus-go-cli_Darwin_x86_64.tar.gz

# Extract
tar -xzf globus-go-cli_Darwin_x86_64.tar.gz

# Move to PATH
sudo mv globus /usr/local/bin/

# Verify installation
globus --version

docs.title: Windows
docs.text:
1. Download the .zip file from GitHub Releases
  2. Extract the archive
  3. Add the directory containing globus.exe to your PATH

docs.title: Build from Source
docs.text:
If you have Go 1.22+ installed:

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/scttfrdmn/globus-go-cli.git
cd globus-go-cli

# Build
make build

# Or use go directly
go build -o globus

# Move to PATH
sudo mv globus /usr/local/bin/

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
After installation, verify the CLI is working:

globus --version

You should see output like:

globus version 3.39.0-2

docs.title: Shell Completion
docs.text: The CLI supports shell completion for Bash, Zsh, Fish, and PowerShell.

docs.title: Bash
docs.text:
# Add to your ~/.bashrc
source <(globus completion bash)

# Or install permanently
globus completion bash > /etc/bash_completion.d/globus

docs.title: Zsh
docs.text:
# Add to your ~/.zshrc
source <(globus completion zsh)

# Or install permanently
globus completion zsh > "${fpath[1]}/_globus"

docs.title: Fish
docs.text:
globus completion fish | source

# Or install permanently
globus completion fish > ~/.config/fish/completions/globus.fish

docs.title: PowerShell
docs.text:
# Add to your profile
globus completion powershell | Out-String | Invoke-Expression

docs.title: Platform Support
docs.text:
Binaries are provided for:

  • Linux: amd64, arm64
  • macOS: amd64 (Intel), arm64 (Apple Silicon)
  • Windows: amd64

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Now that you have the CLI installed, proceed to the Quick Start guide to authenticate and run your first commands.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: This guide will help you get started with the Globus Go CLI by walking through the essential first steps.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, ensure you have:

  • Installed the Globus Go CLI
  • A Globus account (create one at globus.org)

docs.title: Authentication
docs.text:
The first step is to authenticate with Globus:

globus login

This will:

  1. Open your web browser to the Globus authentication page
  2. Prompt you to log in with your Globus account
  3. Ask you to grant permissions to the CLI
  4. Provide an authorization code to paste back into the terminal

After successful authentication, you'll see:

You have successfully logged in to the Globus CLI!

docs.title: Verify Authentication
docs.text:
Check that you're logged in:

globus auth whoami

This displays your identity information:

{
  "username": "yourname@example.edu",
  "name": "Your Name",
  "email": "yourname@example.edu",
  "identity_id": "aaaaaaaa-bbbb-cccc-dddd-eeeeeeeeeeee"
}

docs.title: List Your Endpoints
docs.text:
View endpoints you have access to:

globus transfer endpoint list

docs.title: View Endpoint Details
docs.text:
Get details about a specific endpoint:

globus transfer endpoint show ENDPOINT_ID

Replace ENDPOINT_ID with an actual endpoint UUID.

docs.title: List Files
docs.text:
Browse files on an endpoint:

globus transfer ls ENDPOINT_ID:/path/to/directory

docs.title: Transfer Files
docs.text:
Transfer a file between two endpoints:

globus transfer transfer \
  --source-endpoint SOURCE_ENDPOINT_ID \
  --dest-endpoint DEST_ENDPOINT_ID \
  --source-path /path/to/source/file.txt \
  --dest-path /path/to/destination/file.txt

Check transfer status:

globus transfer task show TASK_ID

docs.title: Output Formats
docs.text: The CLI supports multiple output formats:

docs.title: JSON Output (Default)
docs.text: globus auth whoami --format json

docs.title: Text Output
docs.text: globus auth whoami --format text

docs.title: Quiet Mode
docs.text:
For scripting, use quiet mode to get minimal output:

globus transfer task list --format json --limit 1 | jq -r '.[0].task_id'

docs.title: Common Options
docs.text:
Most commands support these global options:

Option Description --format Output format: json or text --help Show help for the command --version Show CLI version

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Set common options via environment variables:

# Set default output format
export GLOBUS_CLI_FORMAT=json

# Enable debug output
export GLOBUS_CLI_DEBUG=true

See Environment Variables for a complete list.

docs.title: Command Help
docs.text:
Get help for any command:

globus --help
globus transfer --help
globus transfer task list --help

docs.title: Available Commands
docs.text:
List all available commands:

globus --help

Main command groups:

  • auth - Authentication and identity management
  • transfer - File transfer operations
  • search - Search index management
  • groups - Group membership management
  • flows - Workflow automation
  • timers - Scheduled tasks
  • compute - Distributed computing

docs.title: View Configuration
docs.text: globus config show

docs.title: Set Configuration Values
docs.text: globus config set output_format json

docs.title: Logging Out
docs.text:
When you're done, log out to remove stored credentials:

globus logout

docs.title: Common Tasks
docs.text: Practical examples for common operations with the Globus Go CLI.

docs.title: Transfer a Single File
docs.text:
globus transfer transfer \
  --source-endpoint abc12345-6789-0def-ghij-klmnopqrstuv \
  --dest-endpoint xyz67890-abcd-efgh-ijkl-mnopqrstuvwx \
  --source-path /data/file.txt \
  --dest-path /backup/file.txt \
  --label "Single file transfer"

docs.title: Transfer a Directory Recursively
docs.text:
globus transfer transfer \
  --source-endpoint abc12345-6789-0def-ghij-klmnopqrstuv \
  --dest-endpoint xyz67890-abcd-efgh-ijkl-mnopqrstuvwx \
  --source-path /data/mydir/ \
  --dest-path /backup/mydir/ \
  --recursive \
  --label "Directory backup"

docs.title: Monitor Transfer Progress
docs.text:
# Get task ID from transfer command output
TASK_ID="01234567-89ab-cdef-0123-456789abcdef"

# Check task status
globus transfer task show $TASK_ID

# List all active tasks
globus transfer task list --filter-status ACTIVE

docs.title: Sync Directories
docs.text:
Use sync level to avoid re-transferring unchanged files:

globus transfer transfer \
  --source-endpoint abc12345-6789-0def-ghij-klmnopqrstuv \
  --dest-endpoint xyz67890-abcd-efgh-ijkl-mnopqrstuvwx \
  --source-path /data/ \
  --dest-path /backup/ \
  --recursive \
  --sync-level mtime

Sync levels:

  • exists - Transfer only if file doesn't exist at destination
  • size - Transfer if size differs
  • mtime - Transfer if modification time differs
  • checksum - Transfer if checksum differs (most thorough, slowest)

docs.title: Find an Endpoint
docs.text:
Search for endpoints by name or keyword:

globus transfer endpoint search "Tutorial"

docs.title: List Your Endpoints
docs.text: globus transfer endpoint list --filter-scope my-endpoints

docs.title: Get Endpoint Details
docs.text: globus transfer endpoint show abc12345-6789-0def-ghij-klmnopqrstuv

docs.title: List Directory Contents
docs.text: globus transfer ls abc12345-6789-0def-ghij-klmnopqrstuv:/data/

docs.title: Show File Details
docs.text: globus transfer ls abc12345-6789-0def-ghij-klmnopqrstuv:/data/file.txt --long

docs.title: Extract Task ID
docs.text:
TASK_ID=$(globus transfer transfer \
  --source-endpoint SRC \
  --dest-endpoint DST \
  --source-path /src/path \
  --dest-path /dst/path \
  --format json | jq -r '.task_id')

echo "Task ID: $TASK_ID"

docs.title: Count Active Tasks
docs.text: globus transfer task list --filter-status ACTIVE --format json | jq 'length'

docs.title: Extract Endpoint IDs
docs.text: globus transfer endpoint list --format json | jq -r '.[].id'

docs.title: Batch Transfers
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
FILES="file1.txt file2.txt file3.txt"

for file in $FILES; do
  globus transfer transfer \
    --source-endpoint $SRC_EP \
    --dest-endpoint $DST_EP \
    --source-path "/data/$file" \
    --dest-path "/backup/$file" \
    --label "Backup $file"
done

docs.title: Check and Wait for Completion
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
TASK_ID=$1

while true; do
  STATUS=$(globus transfer task show $TASK_ID --format json | jq -r '.status')

  if [ "$STATUS" = "SUCCEEDED" ]; then
    echo "Transfer completed successfully"
    exit 0
  elif [ "$STATUS" = "FAILED" ]; then
    echo "Transfer failed"
    exit 1
  fi

  echo "Status: $STATUS - waiting..."
  sleep 10
done

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: The Globus Go CLI recognizes several environment variables for configuration.

docs.title: GLOBUS_CLI_FORMAT
docs.text:
Set the default output format.

export GLOBUS_CLI_FORMAT=json  # or 'text'

docs.title: GLOBUS_CLI_DEBUG
docs.text:
Enable debug output.

export GLOBUS_CLI_DEBUG=true

docs.title: GLOBUS_CLIENT_ID
docs.text:
Client ID for client credentials authentication.

export GLOBUS_CLIENT_ID=your-client-id

docs.title: GLOBUS_CLIENT_SECRET
docs.text:
Client secret for client credentials authentication.

export GLOBUS_CLIENT_SECRET=your-client-secret

Warning

Never commit client secrets to version control. Use secret management tools in production.

docs.title: GLOBUS_CONFIG_DIR
docs.text:
Override the default configuration directory location.

export GLOBUS_CONFIG_DIR=/custom/path/to/config

Default locations:

  • Linux/macOS: ~/.globus
  • Windows: %USERPROFILE%\.globus

docs.title: GLOBUS_CLI_SYNC_LEVEL
docs.text:
Set the default sync level for transfers.

export GLOBUS_CLI_SYNC_LEVEL=mtime

Values: exists, size, mtime, checksum

docs.title: Bash Example
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

# Set output to JSON for parsing
export GLOBUS_CLI_FORMAT=json

# Authenticate with client credentials
export GLOBUS_CLIENT_ID=abc123
export GLOBUS_CLIENT_SECRET=secret456

# Run commands
globus auth whoami
globus transfer endpoint list

docs.title: Python Example
docs.text:
import os
import subprocess

# Set environment
os.environ['GLOBUS_CLI_FORMAT'] = 'json'

# Run command
result = subprocess.run(
    ['globus', 'auth', 'whoami'],
    capture_output=True,
    text=True
)
print(result.stdout)

docs.title: Priority Order
docs.text:
Configuration values are resolved in this order (highest to lowest):

  1. Command-line flags (--format json)
  2. Environment variables (GLOBUS_CLI_FORMAT=json)
  3. Configuration file (~/.globus/config.yml)
  4. Default values

docs.title: Migration from Python CLI
docs.text: Guide for users migrating from the Python Globus CLI to the Go CLI.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Python CLI:

pipx install globus-cli

Go CLI:

brew install globus-go-cli

See Installation for more options.

docs.title: Command Compatibility
docs.text:
The Go CLI maintains command compatibility with the Python CLI. Most commands work identically:

# These work the same in both CLIs
globus login
globus auth whoami
globus transfer task list
globus search index list

docs.title: Additional Features
docs.text:
The Go CLI includes the Compute service, which is not available in the Python CLI:

globus compute endpoint list
globus compute function register

docs.title: Token Storage
docs.text:
Both CLIs store tokens in the same location:

  • Linux/macOS: ~/.globus/tokens.json
  • Windows: %USERPROFILE%\.globus\tokens.json

Tip

You can use both CLIs with the same authentication tokens.

docs.title: Configuration Files
docs.text: Configuration format is compatible between both CLIs.

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text:
Default output format differs:

  • Python CLI: Text format by default
  • Go CLI: JSON format by default

Set JSON as default in Go CLI:

export GLOBUS_CLI_FORMAT=json

docs.title: Performance
docs.text:
The Go CLI offers:

  • Faster startup - No Python interpreter overhead
  • Lower memory usage - Compiled binary vs interpreted Python
  • Single binary - No dependency management

docs.title: Feature Parity
docs.text: Feature Python CLI Go CLI Auth ✅ ✅ Transfer ✅ ✅ Search ✅ ✅ Groups ✅ ✅ Flows ✅ ✅ Timers ✅ ✅ Compute ❌ ✅

docs.title: Command Names
docs.text: All core commands use identical names. No changes needed to existing scripts.

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text: Default output format differs as noted above. Explicitly specify --format in scripts for consistency.

docs.title: Shell Completion
docs.text:
Both CLIs support shell completion for Bash, Zsh, Fish, and PowerShell.

Python CLI:

eval "$(globus --completion bash)"

Go CLI:

source <(globus completion bash)

docs.title: Migration Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Install Go CLI using preferred method
  • [ ] Verify authentication works: globus auth whoami
  • [ ] Test critical commands from your scripts
  • [ ] Update scripts to specify --format explicitly
  • [ ] Update shell completion configuration
  • [ ] Test transfers and verify expected behavior
  • [ ] Update documentation to reference Go CLI

docs.title: Side-by-Side Usage
docs.text:
You can run both CLIs simultaneously:

  • Use globus for Go CLI (if installed via package manager)
  • Use python -m globus_cli for Python CLI

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you encounter issues during migration:

  • Check Command Reference
  • Review Common Tasks
  • Open an issue on GitHub

docs.text:
• Quick Start

docs.title: Output Formats
docs.text: The Globus Go CLI supports multiple output formats for different use cases.

docs.title: JSON (Default)
docs.text:
Machine-readable JSON output, ideal for parsing and automation:

globus auth whoami --format json

Output:

{
  "username": "user@example.edu",
  "name": "User Name",
  "email": "user@example.edu",
  "identity_id": "aaaaaaaa-bbbb-cccc-dddd-eeeeeeeeeeee"
}

docs.title: Text
docs.text:
Human-readable tabular output:

globus auth whoami --format text

Output:

Username      user@example.edu
Name          User Name
Email         user@example.edu
Identity ID   aaaaaaaa-bbbb-cccc-dddd-eeeeeeeeeeee

docs.title: Via Configuration
docs.text: globus config set output_format json

docs.title: Via Environment Variable
docs.text: export GLOBUS_CLI_FORMAT=json

docs.title: Via Flag
docs.text: globus auth whoami --format text

docs.title: Using jq
docs.text:
Extract specific fields:

# Get just the username
globus auth whoami --format json | jq -r '.username'

# Get identity ID
globus auth whoami --format json | jq -r '.identity_id'

List processing:

# Get all endpoint IDs
globus transfer endpoint list --format json | jq -r '.[].id'

# Get endpoint names and IDs
globus transfer endpoint list --format json | \
  jq -r '.[] | "\(.display_name): \(.id)"'

docs.title: Using Python
docs.text:
import subprocess
import json

result = subprocess.run(
    ['globus', 'auth', 'whoami', '--format', 'json'],
    capture_output=True,
    text=True
)

data = json.loads(result.stdout)
print(f"Username: {data['username']}")

docs.title: Always Specify Format
docs.text:
Don't rely on defaults in scripts:

# Good
globus auth whoami --format json

# Avoid
globus auth whoami

docs.title: Check Exit Codes
docs.text:
if globus auth whoami --format json > /dev/null 2>&1; then
  echo "Authenticated"
else
  echo "Not authenticated"
  exit 1
fi

docs.title: Handle Errors
docs.text:
output=$(globus transfer task show $TASK_ID --format json 2>&1)

if [ $? -ne 0 ]; then
  echo "Error: $output"
  exit 1
fi

echo "$output" | jq .

docs.title: Command Reference
docs.text: Complete reference documentation for all Globus Go CLI commands.

docs.title: Command Structure
docs.text:
All commands follow this structure:

globus <service> <command> [subcommand] [flags]

Example:

globus transfer task list --limit 10

docs.title: Available Services
docs.text: The CLI provides commands for these Globus services:

docs.title: Auth Commands
docs.text:
Authentication and identity management.

globus auth whoami
globus login
globus logout

docs.title: Transfer Commands
docs.text:
File and directory transfer operations.

globus transfer task list
globus transfer ls ENDPOINT_ID:/path
globus transfer transfer --source-endpoint SRC --dest-endpoint DST ...

docs.title: Search Commands
docs.text:
Search index management and queries.

globus search index list
globus search query "search terms"

docs.title: Groups Commands
docs.text:
Group membership and policy management.

globus groups list

docs.title: Flows Commands

Workflow automation and management.

globus flows list

docs.title: Timers Commands

Scheduled task execution.

globus timers list

docs.title: Compute Commands
docs.text:
Distributed computing operations (Go CLI exclusive feature).

globus compute endpoint list
globus compute function register

docs.title: Global Flags
docs.text:
These flags are available for all commands:

Flag Description --format string Output format: json or text (default: json) --help Show help for the command --version Show CLI version

docs.text:
Get help for any command:

docs.title: Exit Codes
docs.text:
The CLI uses standard exit codes:

  • 0 - Success

  • 2 - Command-line syntax error

docs.title: Transfer Commands
docs.text: Commands for file and directory transfer operations.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Transfer service provides commands for:

  • Listing files and directories on endpoints
  • Initiating file transfers between endpoints
  • Managing transfer tasks
  • Working with bookmarks

docs.title: globus transfer ls
docs.text:
List contents of a directory on an endpoint.

globus transfer ls ENDPOINT_ID:/path [flags]

Example:

globus transfer ls abc12345-6789-0def-ghij-klmnopqrstuv:/~/

docs.title: globus transfer transfer
docs.text:
Initiate a file or directory transfer.

globus transfer transfer [flags]

Required Flags:

  • --source-endpoint - Source endpoint UUID
  • --dest-endpoint - Destination endpoint UUID
  • --source-path - Source file or directory path
  • --dest-path - Destination path

Optional Flags:

  • --recursive - Transfer directories recursively
  • --sync-level - Sync level (exists, size, mtime, checksum)
  • --label - Task label

Example:

globus transfer transfer \
  --source-endpoint abc12345-6789-0def-ghij-klmnopqrstuv \
  --dest-endpoint xyz67890-abcd-efgh-ijkl-mnopqrstuvwx \
  --source-path /path/to/source \
  --dest-path /path/to/dest \
  --recursive

docs.title: globus transfer task list
docs.text:
List recent transfer tasks.

globus transfer task list [flags]

Flags:

  • --limit - Maximum number of tasks to return
  • --filter-status - Filter by status (ACTIVE, INACTIVE, SUCCEEDED, FAILED)

Example:

globus transfer task list --limit 10 --filter-status ACTIVE

docs.title: globus transfer task show
docs.text:
Show details for a specific transfer task.

globus transfer task show TASK_ID

docs.title: globus transfer task cancel
docs.text:
Cancel a transfer task.

globus transfer task cancel TASK_ID

docs.title: globus transfer endpoint show

globus transfer endpoint show ENDPOINT_ID

docs.title: globus transfer endpoint search

globus transfer endpoint search SEARCH_TERMS [flags]
